qas.question: What are the two types of Ion gauges?
What affects the number of ions in a gauge?
What gauge is accurate from 10-2 torr to 10-9 torr?
What must be used for accurate measurement on the composition of gases at a high vacuums?

answers.text: mass spectrometer must be used in conjunction with the ionization gauge

qas.question: Why does a mass spectrometer need to be used with gauge to be accurate at high vacuum gas measurement?

answers.text: composition of gases at high vacuums will usually be unpredictable

qas.question: What are the two types of mass spectrometers?
In the hot cathode version what does corrosion produce?
What is ionized when electrodes travel through a mass spectrometer?
What is the accuracy of a mass spectrometer?
What is the nature of electrically heated filaments at high vacuums?

context: Ion gauges are used in ultrahigh vacuum. They come in two types: <a0_0><b5_0>hot cathode and cold cathode<b5_0/>.<a0_0/> In the hot cathode version an electrically heated filament produces <b6_0>an electron beam<b6_0/>. The electrons travel through the gauge and ionize <b7_0>gas molecules<b7_0/> around them. The resulting ions are collected at a negative electrode. The current depends on the number of ions, which depends on <a1_0>the pressure in the gauge<a1_0/>. Hot cathode gauges are accurate from 10−3 torr to 10−10 torr. The principle behind cold cathode version is the same, except that electrons are produced in a discharge created by a high voltage electrical discharge. <a2_0>Cold cathode gauges<a2_0/> are accurate <b8_0>from 10−2 torr to 10−9 torr<b8_0/>. Ionization gauge calibration is very sensitive to construction geometry, chemical composition of gases being measured, corrosion and surface deposits. Their calibration can be invalidated by activation at atmospheric pressure or low vacuum. The <a4_0>composition of gases at high vacuums will usually be <b9_0>unpredictable<b9_0/><a4_0/>, so a <a3_0>mass spectrometer must be used in conjunction with the ionization gauge<a3_0/> for accurate measurement.
